p: The mercury chemistry scheme applied in the mercury sub-model of DEHM is based on the Tropospheric Chemistry Module (TCM) [ 21], which consists of three gas phase compounds: Hg 0, HgO, HgCl 2; 1 particulate phase Hg and nine aqueous phase compounds. Ozone is the most important oxidant for the formation of reactive gaseous mercury (RGM) and total particulate mercury (TPM) in this scheme. An additional fast oxidation rate of Hg 0 to HgO is assumed during polar sunrise over sea-ice in the Arctic in order to simulate the Atmospheric Mercury Depletion Events (AMDEs), which accounts for up to about half of the deposition from the atmosphere [ 3, 4, 5]. It is a simple, but useful parameterization [ 4]. Theoretical studies suggest that reactions with atomic bromine (Br) can account for the reactivity of Hg during AMDEs [ 22]. The understanding of these processes is not yet complete [ 13], and they are not included in the model version applied in this study.
